post.subject: Re: 21 Jan. 2013 - 3: Z-Transform
post.message: One should keep track of the ROC, at least mentally.  ROC is the region where the Z-transform converges.  As a result, different terms of a partial fraction can have different ROCs.  For example, see Example 4.29 in the book, page 99.

post.subject: Re: 21 Jan. 2013 - 3: Z-Transform
post.message: The phrase "causal signal" is not rigorously defined as a "causal system".  In fact, this phrase is introduced mainly for convenience.  Of course, if you view it as the output of a causal system, then it makes more sense.  Instead of using some k, please use the "current" time - in this case the problems you have raised do not arise.

post.subject: Re: 21 Jan. 2013 - 3: Z-Transform
post.message:
If we have/design a system which needs the input sample at a later sampling instant (to calculate the output at the current instant), then that system becomes non - causal. (i.e., it depends on future inputs). e.g., y(n) = u(n+1). As you have suggested, such systems will never get future inputs at the given instant and cannot be realised in practise. This is the reason why a controller design should be done carefully to produce only causal systems/designs.

Rakhi

post.subject: Re: 21 Jan. 2013 - 3: Z-Transform
post.message:
Past input refers to what inputs already occurred and future input refers to the yet to be applied inputs.


Causal system is one that responds "after" an input is applied.  This is what we deal with in real life systems, especially in control applications.  So your question could have been, "what is the need for a noncausal system?", as these respond even before an input is applied.  I have already answered this question as a reply to Patel Pranavkumar's post.

post.subject: Re: 21 Jan. 2013 - 3: Z-Transform
post.message: These concepts are very similar whether you are dealing with difference equations or with differential equations.  You may refer to DSP by Proakis and Manolakis or Signals and Systems by Openheim, Wilsky and Young.

post.subject: Re: 21 Jan. 2013 - 3: Z-Transform
post.message: Correlation is used heavily in identification problems - you can see it chapter 6 of the textbook.  It helps find the relation between two signals - for example, input and output.  It will not be used so much in the current course.  Convolution, on the other hand, is used to find the response of a linear system.
